Required Text:　　A required packet of photocopied readings and handouts
Recommended Text:　　How to Design and Deliver Speeches (8th edition), Fletcher, L. Pearson, 2004.
Course Description: 　　This course aims to establish the foundation for English-major students to deliver public speeches in English. Students learn to select topics, collect essential information, analyze the audience, organize materials, improve delivery skills, distinguish different types of speeches, and further to evaluate their own and others’ speeches. Each student is expected to deliver at least 3 individual speeches, and 2-3 debates. Speech topics will be assigned to students. Any modifications of the speech topics will have to be approved by the instructor. All student speech sessions must be videotaped.(*1)
Course Requirements: 　　Students’ responsibilities in this class include:
(1)　　to attend class regularly and to arrive on time: a sign-in sheet to record attendance / a grade reduction of 5% of the semester grade for each class session missed absence
(2)　　to present materials assigned
(3)　　to deliver speeches as scheduled:
i.　　Students are required to present their speeches on the day scheduled;
ii.　　Make-up speech will be allowed only when the failure to perform is due to an officially excused absence at the instructor’s discretion.
iii.　　The ideal time duration for each speech is 4 to 6 minutes. The minimum length of speech time is 3 minutes, and the maximum 6 minutes. Violation of the time limit (less than 3 and more than 6) will create a 10-point deduction. The time length for debates will vary due to the different formats employed.
(4)　　to submit the speech script and outlining structure (see Appendix 1) to the instructor when presenting the speech. Failure to submit will generate a penalty of 20 points (out of 100) in each speech. Students who fail to comply with the outline format requirements (sampled and specified below)will forfeit the opportunity to deliver the current speech / debate.
(5)　　to evaluate one’s own speech: speeches will be videotaped and given back to the speakers. Student speakers are required to watch their own videotaped performance, observe their own speeches, and later submit a self-evaluating commentary to the instructor. Facilities and technical support will be provided by the department. A portfolio needs to be established and submitted at the semester end.
(6)　　to offer constructive opinions and feedbacks of the fellow students as speakers: Students are encouraged to give verbal / oral commentary of the fellow students’ speeches, and with the objectively constructed criticism, the student evaluators will earn 3% grade points to their semester grades.
Grading Policy: 　　(1) Academic honesty is prioritized in this class. Students should learn that plagiarism will not be tolerated. Students will fail the course without contention once an incident of plagiarism is identified in their submitted writing or presented speech.
(2) The grading components are as follows:

Topics for Informative Speeches
Topic Area 1) Media Power, Ethics & Control: what, why and how (the impact)
Topic Area 2) Sustainable Development: what, why and how (the impact)
Topic Area 3) Poverty Gap: what, why and how (the status quo and the impact)
Topic Area 4) Euthanasia: what, why and how (the status quo and impact)
Topics for Persuasive Speeches
Topic Area 1) Media Power, Ethics & Control: what, why and how (the impact)
(1)　　Media censorship
(2)　　Media language and public interpretation
(3)　　Public rights to know vs. privacy
(4)　　Journalistic integrity: hard news vs. infotainment
Topic Area 2) Sustainable Development: what, why and how (the impact)
(1)　　Why an inconvenient truth?
(2)　　Science and politics of global warming
Topic Area 3) Poverty Gap: what, why and how (the status quo and the impact)
(1)　　Globalization: enlarging or shrinking the poverty gap?
(2)　　The wealthy pyramid: the building blocks from bottom to top (what and where to find?)
(3)　　Being averagely wealthy: Is it possible?
(4)　　Wealth concentration vs. wealth distribution
(5)　　How short the gap to create total human welfare?
Topic Area 4) Euthanasia: what, why and how (the status quo and impact)
(1)　　To live or not to live: whose choice is it?
(2)　　Mercy killing and assisted suicide: which is which?
(3)　　Legal issues vs. ethical issues
(4)　　Palliative care: at what / whose cost?
Note:
Students enrolled in English Public Speaking and Debates are encouraged to develop their own speech topics or modify the current topics based on the designated topic issues at least two weeks prior to the scheduled speech session. All topics need to be approved by the instructor.
